23.d: Petroleum is a liquid natural resource from which many fuels are made.
23.s: → The petroleum at that factory is used to make gasoline.

23.d: A prototype is a new machine that is not ready to be made in large quantities.
23.s: → He introduced his prototype to the motorcycle company.

23.d: A scrap of something is a small amount of it.

23.d: A sector is a part of a country’s economy in a specific type of industry.

23.d: To subscribe to something is to agree or to concur with it.

23.d: To subsist means to have the food, water, and money needed to stay alive.
23.s: → Some people are forced to subsist on only a few dollars a month.

23.d: To suspend something means to delay or stop it from happening for a while.
23.s: → The oil company suspended production until it was sure the factory was safe.

23.d: A synthesis is a combination of different ideas or styles.
23.s: → The band’s music was a synthesis of many different musical genres.

24.d: An acrobat is a person who entertains people by doing amazing physical things.

24.d: Advocacy is the act of supporting or recommending something.
24.s: → Janine’s strong advocacy for the event made people want to attend.

24.d: If something is communal, it involves a group of people.
24.s: → On the weekends, Theo and his son picked up trash in the communal park.

24.d: If something is fluid, it is smooth and moves gracefully.

24.d: To harmonize means to make different things go well together.

24.d: If someone is industrious, they work hard.
24.s: → Dennis was very industrious, so he never had problems finding a job.

24.d: When someone is inventive, they are good at creating new things.
24.s: → The inventive student built a robot to help her with her chores.

24.d: If something is judicial, it is related to judges or courts of law.

24.d: Mandarin is one of the two main Chinese languages.
24.s: → Although John’s parents both spoke Mandarin, he could only speak English.

24.d: If something is metropolitan, it relates to a large city.

24.d: To mimic something means to copy the way it sounds or moves.
24.s: → The hunter mimicked a duck’s call and shot the two ducks that called back.

24.d: When something is misguided, it is based on bad judgment or wrong beliefs.

24.d: To rehearse means to practice and prepare for a performance in front of people.
24.s: → Vick’s band rehearsed all week before their first show.

24.d: To scorn someone means to behave without respect toward them.

24.d: If something is sensory, it is related to the senses.

24.d: If something is staple, it is standard or basic.

24.d: A statute is a law that is official and has been written down.
24.s: → The new statute made it illegal to walk dogs in the park.

24.d: A veteran is someone who has a lot of experience doing something.

24.d: A villain is an evil person who breaks the law or hurts others.
24.s: → The villain escaped with half of my family’s valuables.

24.d: A vine is a plant that has long, twisting stems and climbs upward.

25.d: To constrain something means to limit its development.

25.d: A depot is a bus or train station.

25.d: To emulate people means to imitate them because they are greatly admired.

25.d: The forefinger is the finger between one’s thumb and middle finger.

25.d: The guts are all the organs inside a person or animal.

25.d: When something is inherent, it is a natural part of something else.
25.s: → Sweating is an inherent bodily function when exercising.

25.d: To intimidate means to frighten others.
25.s: → My dad intimidates my friends whenever they visit.

25.d: A janitor is a person who makes repairs and takes care of a building.

25.d: When something is moist, it is slightly wet.
25.s: → The ground is still moist from the rain last night.

25.d: Nope is an informal way of saying “ no.”
25.s: → He asked if I had any money, and I had to say, “Nope. ”

25.d: To prod means to push someone or something with a finger or pointed object.
25.s: → The bully prodded me in the chest with his finger.

25.d: A ransom is a sum of money paid to a kidnapper to set the person free.
25.s: → He kidnapped the prince and demanded $1 million as ransom.

25.d: To restrain someone or something means to use physical strength to stop them.
25.s: → Mike restrained Allen from reaching the door.

25.d: Saliva is the watery liquid in people’s mouths that helps in digestion.
25.s: → The baby could not keep the saliva from dripping out of its mouth.

25.d: To spit means to force liquid from one’s mouth.
25.s: → He emerged from the pool and spit water from his mouth.

25.d: To sprint means to run very fast over a short distance.

25.d: A stunt is something that is done in order to get attention or publicity.
25.s: → The man jumped over the cars as a promotional stunt.

25.d: When people are tolerant, they are approved of because they accept others.
25.s: → The tolerant leader thought that everyone was equal regardless of race.

25.d: A vampire is a fictional monster that sleeps in a coffin and sucks people’s blood.
25.s: → The vampire snuck up on the woman and bit her in the neck.

25.d: To yawn means to open one’s mouth wide and breathe in air.
25.s: → The child yawned and stretched her arms before bed for the night.

26.d: An analogy is a connection made between things to show that they are similar.
26.s: → The doctor made an analogy between the human heart and a water pump.

26.d: A person's ancestry is the series of people from whom a person descended.
26.s: → We studied our ancestry and found out that we are related to royalty.

26.d: An archer is a person who uses a bow and arrows.
26.s: → The expert archer hit the target every time.

26.d: A conspiracy is a secret plan made by a group of people to do something illegal.

26.d: A deputy is the second-highest-ranking person in a business or government.
26.s: → While the sheriff was ill, the deputy took over his duties.

26.d: An earl is a nobleman from Britain.

26.d: When something is fragrant, it has a pleasant smell.
26.s: → The girl picked delicious berries and fragrant flowers.

26.d: A funnel is an object with a wide top and a narrow bottom for pouring liquids.
26.s: → The worker used a funnel when he poured the oil into the engine.

26.d: If something is hereditary, it is a trait passed onto children from their parents.

26.d: A hymn is a religious song that often praises a god.

26.d: To invert something means to turn it upside down.
26.s: → He inverted the bicycle to make repairs on the wheels.

26.d: Prey is the animals that are hunted and eaten by another creature.
26.s: → The lion ran as fast as he could to catch his prey.

26.d: A procession is a group of people who walk or drive in a line during a public event.
26.s: → The procession all celebrated when they reached the end.

26.d: A prophet is a person chosen by a god to give the god’s message to people.
26.s: → Harold believed that he was one of the prophets of his god.

26.d: When something is sarcastic, it is the opposite of what is actually meant.
26.s: → She hurt her mother’s feelings with her constant sarcastic remarks.

26.d: Seasoning is a mix of salt, herbs, and spices that improves the taste of food.
26.s: → This steak tastes bland. Maybe I’ll add some seasoning to it.

26.d: Sodium is an element that can be used to make substances such as salt.
26.s: → Sodium and chloride combine to make table salt.

26.d: A tyranny is a cruel and unfair government in which one person has power.

26.d: A tyrant is someone who treats people in a cruel, harsh, and unfair way.
26.s: → Our boss is a tyrant. He makes us work long hours for little pay.

26.d: Vinegar is a strong liquid made from sour wine that is used in cooking.
26.s: → Be careful because too much vinegar will ruin the recipe.

27.d: If something is adjoining, it is next to or joined with a building, or room.

27.d: To allege something is to say that it is true without offering proof.
27.s: → The little girl had alleged that her older brother hid her favorite doll.

27.d: An arch is a curved opening formed under a structure such as a bridge or doorway.

27.d: To assemble means to get together in one place.
27.s: → The parents assembled to discuss ways to improve their children’s education.

27.d: A casualty is a person killed or injured in a war or an accident.
27.s: → The only casualty in the car accident was a woman who broke her arm.

27.d: To erect something means to build it.
27.s: → The king erected two towers on the north and south sides of his castle.

27.d: If something is foul, then it is not pleasant or enjoyable.
27.s: → He wouldn’t let his dog drink from the water because it had a foul smell.

27.d: A hectare is a unit of measure equal to 10,000 square meters.
27.s: → His family farm covered many hectares.

27.d: To heighten an emotion means to increase the intensity of it.

27.d: Hospitality is friendly behavior and entertainment given to guests or strangers.
27.s: → The travelers were amazed at the hospitality given them by the hotel’s staff.

27.d: A mansion is a large and expensive home.
27.s: → The mansion had thirty bedrooms, two kitchens, and a pool.

27.d: To outnumber a group means to have a greater number than it.
27.s: → The girls outnumbered the boys at the school by four to one.

27.d: If someone is overjoyed, then they are extremely happy.

27.d: A pasture is an area of land covered with grass for animals to use as food.
27.s: → The sheep were taken to a pasture where there was more grass.

27.d: A petition is a written request asking an authority to do something.
27.s: → The citizens all signed a petition asking the mayor to repair the sidewalks.

27.d: To renovate a building means to repair it or build new structures on it.
27.s: → The old fire station was renovated into an apartment building.

27.d: To revise something means to change or update it to make it better.
27.s: → When the editor discovered certain facts were wrong, he revised the book.

27.d: A slab is a large, thick, flat piece of stone, concrete, metal, or wood.

27.d: A terrace is an open area that is connected to a house or an apartment.
27.s: → In the afternoons, she liked to sit on the terrace and check her email.

27.d: Turf is a section of grass and the dirt in which it grows.
27.s: → After the game, the turf looked ragged.

28.d: If something is analogous to another thing, then it is like it in certain ways.

28.d: Binoculars are a device used for seeing things that are far away.
28.s: → He could see the ship on the horizon only if he used his binoculars.

28.d: The bulk of something is its great size.

28.d: If something comprises something else, it consists of or is made up of it.

28.d: To depict something means to show or portray it, often using art.
28.s: → The statue’s face depicted the general’s determination and courage.

28.d: If something is dual, then it is made up of two parts.
28.s: → The room had a dual function. It was a living room, but at night it was a bedroom.

28.d: Fahrenheit temperature is a scale where water freezes at 32° and boils at 212°.
28.s: → When the temperature dropped to 32° Fahrenheit, it started snowing.

28.d: To fulfill something means to achieve or finish it.

28.d: A grove is a small group of trees.
28.s: → All the trees in this grove are apple trees.

28.d: Ore is the raw form of rock or material from which a valuable metal is taken.
28.s: → The factory melted the ore and used it to make iron products.

28.d: The outback is the wild inland region of Australia where very few people live.
28.s: → Many Australian farmers use the outback to raise cattle.

28.d: To outweigh something means to exceed it in value, amount, or importance.

28.d: A paradox is a true statement or real event that seems illogical.

28.d: A pier is a structure that extends into a body of water.

28.d: A shortcut is a route that is shorter than the main route.
28.s: → We got to the house first because we took a shortcut through the forest.

28.d: A tariff is a tax or fee paid on certain imports or exports.
28.s: → Our tariff on imported wool makes foreign wool more expensive.

28.d: A thermometer is a device that measures temperature.
28.s: → The thermometer outside the window indicated that it was a hot day today.

28.d: To tilt something means to tip it into a sloping position.
28.s: → She tilted her glass and almost spilled some of the wine inside.

28.d: If a statement is vice versa, then its two main ideas are switched with one another.

28.d: The whereabouts of someone or something is the place where they are.

29.d: Amber is a hard, yellowish material that comes from trees.

29.d: Charcoal is a black material that is used as fuel for fire.

29.d: A columnist is a writer who creates articles about a particular subject.

29.d: When someone is courteous, they are polite and respectful.

29.d: Credentials are the proof of someone’s experience or ability to do something.

29.d: A cricket is an insect that makes loud noises, usually at night.

29.d: Detergent is soap that is used to clean clothes or dishes.

29.d: Granite is a very hard type of rock that is often black or pink.

29.d: Gravel is a combination of small stones mixed with sand.
29.s: → The ground around the swing set was covered with gravel.

29.d: To haunt is to cause problems or negative thoughts over a long period of time.
29.s: → His thoughts about his scary dream haunted him for weeks.

29.d: When someone is liberal, they accept different ideas and people.

29.d: A maze is a system of paths that is complicated and easy to get lost in.
29.s: → We got lost in the maze in the garden.

29.d: Moss is a small green or yellow plant that grows on wet dirt, rocks, or tree trunks.
29.s: → Be careful not to slip on the moss that’s covering those rocks.

29.d: A pebble is a small, round stone.
29.s: → We threw pebbles into the lake to make the water splash.

29.d: When a bird pecks, it bites or hits something with its beak.

29.d: A reservoir is a place for storing water for a town to use.
29.s: → If it doesn’t rain soon, the reservoir is going to dry up completely.

29.s: → Her hair was brown except for a streak which she dyed blonde.
